sentences: Agneta Åse Fältskog (born 5 April 1950), known as Agnetha Fältskog (Swedish pronunciation:
section: N/A

sentences: [aŋˈnêːta ˈfɛ̂ltskuːɡ] (listen)),  is a Swedish singer, songwriter, musician and actress.
section: N/A

sentences: She first achieved success in Sweden with the release of her 1968 self-titled debut album, and later achieved international stardom in the 1970s as a member of the pop group ABBA.
section: N/A

sentences: The group has sold over 180 million albums and singles worldwide, making it one of the best-selling music acts in history.
section: N/A

sentences: After the unofficial break-up of ABBA in December 1982, Fältskog found renewed success later in the decade as a solo artist with three albums and a leading role in a movie.
section: N/A

sentences: She became reclusive in the 1990s, avoiding outside publicity and residing on the Stockholm County island of Ekerö.
section: N/A

sentences: Fältskog stopped recording music for 16 years until she released a new album, My Colouring Book, in 2004.
section: N/A

sentences: She returned again in 2013 with A, her highest UK charting solo album to date.
section: N/A

sentences: ABBA since has reformed, and Fältskog has resumed her previous role with the group.

== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: Early life =
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===
== Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: Agneta Åse Fältskog was born in Jönköping, Sweden on 5 April 1950.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: She was the first of two daughters of department store manager Knut Ingvar Fältskog (1922–1995) and his wife Birgit Margareta Johansson (1923–1994).
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: Ingvar showed much interest in music and show business, and Birgit devoted herself to her children and household.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: Fältskog's younger sister, Mona, was born in 1955.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: Fältskog wrote her first song at the age of six, entitled "Två små troll" ("Two Small Trolls").
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: In 1958, she began taking piano lessons, and also sang in a local church choir.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: In early 1960, Fältskog formed a musical trio, the Cambers, with her friends Lena Johansson and Elisabeth Strub.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: They performed locally in minor venues and soon dissolved due to a lack of engagements.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: At age 15, Fältskog decided to leave school and pursue a career.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===

sentences: Fältskog cites Connie Francis, Marianne Faithfull, Aretha Franklin and Lesley Gore as her strongest musical influences.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life ===
== Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: Career development in Sweden (1966–1971)
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===
== Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: Fältskog worked as a telephonist for a car firm while performing with a local dance band, headed by Bernt Enghardt.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: The band soon became so popular that she had to make a choice between her job and her musical career.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: She continued singing with the Bernt Enghardt band for two years.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: During that time, Fältskog broke up with her boyfriend Björn Lilja; this event inspired her to write a song, "Jag var så kär" ("I Was So in Love"), that soon brought her to media prominence.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: At that time, Karl Gerhard Lundkvist, a relative of one of the band's members, retired from his successful rock and roll career and began working as a record producer at Cupol Records.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: Enghardt sent him a demo recording of the band, but Lundkvist only showed interest in Fältskog and her song.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: She was worried because he was not interested in the band and they were not to be included on the record.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: However, she decided to accept the offer, and signed a recording contract with Cupol Records.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: Her self-penned début single "Jag var så kär" was recorded on 16 October 1967 and released through Cupol Records the following month.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: It topped the Swedish Chart on 28 January 1968 and sold more than 80,000 copies.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: She also submitted the song "Försonade" ("Reconciled") to Melodifestivalen, the Swedish preliminary for the Eurovision Song Contest, but it was not selected for the final.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: Fältskog developed a career as one of Sweden's most popular pop music artists, participating in a television special about Swedish composer Jules Sylvain in 1969.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: The same year, she released the single "Zigenarvän" ("Gypsy Friend") about a young girl attending a Gypsy wedding and falling in love with the bride's brother.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: Its release coincided with a heated debate about Gypsies in the Swedish media, and Fältskog was accused of deliberately trying to make money out of the situation by writing the song.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: Fältskog's success continued throughout the late 1960s.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: She met German songwriter/producer Dieter Zimmermann, to whom she became engaged.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: Her albums thus reached the German charts, and Zimmermann promised her she would achieve great success in Germany.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: However, when she went there and met with record producers, the venture was not productive; Fältskog refused to meet the demands of the producers, describing their chosen material as "horrible".
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: She soon ended her engagement to Zimmermann and returned to Sweden.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: In 1970, she released "Om tårar vore guld" ("If Tears Were Gold").
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: The Danish composer Per Hviid claimed that she used 22 bars from his composition "Tema" ("Theme"), even though it  was written in the 1950s and had never been recorded.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: The case dragged on until 1977, when a settlement was reached and Fältskog paid the Danish musician SEK 5,000.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===

sentences: In 1972, Fältskog portrayed Mary Magdalene in the Swedish production of the international hit musical Jesus Christ Superstar.
section: == Life and career == | === Career development in Sweden (1966–1971) ===
== Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982)
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===
== Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Fältskog met Björn Ulvaeus, a member of the Hootenanny Singers, for the first time in 1968, and then again in 1969.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Her relationship with Ulvaeus, as well as her friendship with Anni-Frid Lyngstad and Benny Andersson, with whom Ulvaeus had already written songs, eventually led to the formation of ABBA.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Fältskog and Ulvaeus married on 6 July 1971 in the village of Verum, with Andersson playing the organ at their wedding.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Their first child, Linda Elin Ulvaeus, was born on 23 February 1973, and their son Peter Christian Ulvaeus on 4 December 1977.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: After seven years of marriage, the couple decided to separate in late 1978, and filed for divorce in January 1979.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: The divorce was finalised in July 1980.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Both Fältskog and Ulvaeus agreed not to let their failed marriage interfere with their responsibilities with ABBA.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: The failure of their marriage inspired Ulvaeus to write the lyrics of "The Winner Takes It All".
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: As a member of ABBA, Fältskog was also known as Anna in some countries.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: In 1975, during the same period as her bandmate Anni-Frid Lyngstad recorded her Swedish number one album Frida ensam, Fältskog recorded and produced her solo album Elva kvinnor i ett hus.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: These albums were both recorded between sessions and promotion for the ABBA albums Waterloo and ABBA.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Fältskog's album spent 53 weeks on the Swedish album chart (longer than any of ABBA's albums), but failed to reach the Top 10, peaking at No.11.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: It contained three further Svensktoppen entries for Fältskog: her Swedish-language version of ABBA's "SOS" (also No. 4 on the single sales chart); "Tack För En Underbar Vanlig Dag"; and "Doktorn!".
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: With the exception of "SOS", all the songs had lyrics by Bosse Carlgren and music by Fältskog herself.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: The creation of the album had been underway since 1972, when Fältskog started writing the songs, but it was delayed because of the work with ABBA and her pregnancy.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: In 1974, Fältskog and Carlgren had agreed on a concept for the album; it should consist of 12 songs, each sung by 12 different female characters living in the same apartment building.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: However, in the end only 11 songs were featured on the album, and the concept wasn't fully developed.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Fältskog possesses a coloratura soprano voice.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: She is noted for her operatic abilities, and her range expands from D3 to Eb6.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Between the years 1968 and 1980, Fältskog had a total of 18 entries on the Svensktoppen radio chart, starting with the debut single "Jag Var Så Kär" in January 1968 (peak position No. 1) and ending with "När Du Tar Mig I Din Famn" ("When You Take Me in Your Arms") from the compilation Tio år med Agnetha in January 1980 (peak position No. 1).
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: These 18 entries, most of which were composed or co-written by Fältskog herself, spent a total of 139 weeks on the chart during this time, with the biggest hit being 1970's "Om tårar vore guld" (No. 1, 15 weeks).
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Fältskog also recorded the Swedish Christmas album Nu tändas tusen juleljus with daughter Linda Ulvaeus which peaked at No. 6 on the Swedish album chart in December 1981.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Fältskog participated in Melodifestivalen again, albeit only as a composer.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: In 1981, she wrote the ballad "Men Natten Är Vår" ("But the Night Is Ours") with lyrics by Ingela Forsman, but instead of performing the song in the contest herself, she chose new talent Kicki Moberg.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: The song placed 9th out of 10.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: The single, which Fältskog produced in the Polar Studios with the same musicians as on contemporary ABBA recordings, was backed with the Swedish version of "I'm Still Alive", entitled "Här Är Mitt Liv" ("Here Is My Life"), a song which she herself had performed in its English version (lyrics by ex-husband Björn Ulvaeus) during ABBA's 1979 world tour.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Moberg's recording of the song remains the only version to have been officially released to date.
section: == Life and career == | === First marriage and years with ABBA (1971–1982) ===

sentences: Although no official announcement was made, ABBA effectively disbanded in late 1982 to early 1983.

sentences: At the end of 1982 Fältskog duetted with Swedish singer (and former ABBA backing vocalist)
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: Tomas Ledin on a song called "Never Again", which became a Top Five hit in Sweden, Norway, Belgium, and South America.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The song was also released in a Spanish-language version, entitled "Ya Nunca Más".
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: In the summer of the same year, Fältskog had a leading role in the Swedish movie Raskenstam.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: In May 1983, Fältskog released her first post-ABBA solo album, Wrap Your Arms Around Me, produced by Mike Chapman.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The album became a moderate hit in North America and Australia, but reached the higher regions of the charts across Europe, including No. 1 in Sweden, Norway, Finland, Belgium, and Denmark (where it became the biggest-selling album of the year), top 5 in Germany, The Netherlands and France and No. 18 in the UK.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The album achieved sales of 1.5 million copies in the first year.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: Two singles from the album became hits in continental Europe: "The Heat Is On" became a No. 1 hit in Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Finland, and Belgium and No. 2 in The Netherlands and Germany.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The song peaked at No. 35 in the UK (and was Fältskog's highest charting and only UK Top 40 hit until 2004).
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The album's title track reached No. 1 in Belgium and peaked at No. 4 in the Netherlands.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: In North America, the album track "Can't Shake Loose" was released as the lead-off single, reaching No. 29 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart, and No. 23 on the RPM Top 50 singles chart in Canada.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: Fältskog's next studio album, Eyes Of A Woman, produced by Eric Stewart of 10cc, was released in March 1985.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: "She is quite content to grace the works of various other lesser mortals with her immaculate, sugar-sweet voice," wrote Barry McIlheney in Melody Maker.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The album sold well in parts of Europe, peaking at No. 2 in Sweden and reaching the Top 20 in Norway and Belgium, but scraped into the UK Top 40 just for one week.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The album sold up to 800,000 copies.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The self-penned lead single "I Won't Let You Go" achieved moderate success in Europe, reaching No. 6 in Sweden, No. 18 in the Netherlands and No. 24 in West Germany.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: In 1986, Fältskog recorded another duet, "The Way You Are", with Swedish singer Ola Håkansson, which became another No. 1 hit in Sweden and Norway.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: In early 1987, Fältskog recorded the album Kom följ med i vår karusell ('Come Join Us On Our Carousel') with her son Christian.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The album contained songs for children and was sung in Swedish.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: For the album Agnetha recorded duets with her son and a children's choir.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: In 1988, it was nominated for Swedish music prize Grammis in a category 'Barn' (For Children).
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: In the summer of 1987, Fältskog travelled to Malibu, California, to record her fourth post-ABBA solo album, I Stand Alone, produced by Peter Cetera (formerly of the band Chicago) and Bruce Gaitsch, who had collaborated on Madonna's La Isla Bonita.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: Released in November of that year, I Stand Alone was a minor hit in Europe, except in Sweden where it spent eight weeks at No. 1 and became the best-selling album of 1988.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: More than 300,000 copies were sold throughout Scandinavia.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: According to Hans Englund, the Swedish head of WEA, more than 800,000 copies were sold globally.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: However, chart-wise outside of Scandinavia, the results were less impressive.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The single "I Wasn't The One (Who Said Goodbye)", on which Fältskog duetted with Peter Cetera, was released primarily in North America, and became her second solo single to chart on the Billboard Hot 100, peaking at No. 93.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: It was also a Top 20 Billboard Adult Contemporary hit.
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: The track (along with "The Last Time" as "La Última Vez") was also recorded in Spanish for the Latin American market as "Yo No Fui Quién Dijo Adiós".
section: == Life and career == | === Solo career development (1982–1988) ===

sentences: Fältskog refused to promote the album in major TV shows in West Germany, but she made a promotional visit to London in February 1988, appearing on the Terry Wogan Show.

== Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: Following the release of I Stand Alone, Fältskog had a 17-year hiatus from the music industry, during which she made few public appearances and devoted much of her time to astrology, yoga and horse riding at her isolated country house in Ekerö.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: In 1990, Fältskog married Swedish surgeon Tomas Sonnenfeld, but the couple divorced in 1993.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: In 1994, Fältskog's mother died by suicide by jumping from her Jönköping apartment balcony.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: Fältskog's resulting depression worsened a year later when her father died.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: In 1997, Fältskog started a relationship with a Dutch forklift driver, Gert van der Graaf.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: After Fältskog decided to terminate the relationship in 1999, he stalked her further at her mansion, resulting in a court issuing Van der Graaf with a restraining order and deporting him to the Netherlands in 2000.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: Returning close to her home in 2003, he was arrested and then banned from entering Sweden.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: In 2005, the ban order from Sweden ran out, and within months Van der Graaf was again sighted near Fältskog's estate in Ekerö.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: In 1996, her autobiography Som jag är was published in Swedish (and in English the following year titled As I Am), followed by several compilation CDs of her Swedish and English recordings, including one called My Love, My Life for which Fältskog picked out the music herself.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: Fans welcomed the autobiography.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

sentences: The book was updated in 1998 and released worldwide via Virgin Publishing, selling over 50,000 copies.
section: == Life and career == | === Hiatus from recording (1988–2004) ===

section: == Life and career == | === Return to music and selected public appearances (2004–present) ===

sentences: The title track, "My Colouring Book", is a cover of the song originally recorded by Barbra Streisand.

sentences: The Observer suggested that "time hasn't diminished her perfect voice."

sentences: She may be cheating a trifle by including no original material on this collection of 1960s covers, but if anyone can do justice to the likes of "Sealed with a Kiss", it's her.

sentences: The soaring sentimentality evokes Cilla Black and Sandie Shaw in their mini-skirted pomp, and I don't say that lightly."

sentences: "Sometimes When I'm Dreaming", originally recorded by Art Garfunkel, failed to be released as the third single.
section: == Life and career == | === Return to music and selected public appearances (2004–present) ===

== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Fältskog had a fear of flying, which worsened during ABBA's 1979 American tour, when the band's plane, heading to Boston, Massachusetts, was short of fuel, hit a tornado and performed an emergency landing.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Fältskog said in 2013 that she still needed therapy to deal with the fear.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: During her solo career years, Fältskog would always travel by bus, and experienced a bus accident on a Swedish motorway in 1983.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Fältskog has reportedly suffered from stage fright, fear of crowds and open spaces, and fear of heights, among others.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Fältskog's split from Ulvaeus in 1979 greatly affected her and she needed therapy afterwards.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Her second marriage in 1990 to Tomas Sonnenfeld was held privately, and only became public knowledge when they divorced three years later.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Her mother's suicide in 1994 and her father's death the following year were also kept private.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Fältskog currently lives in Ekerö, Stockholm County with her son, Christian Ulvaeus, his partner, and their daughter.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Fältskog's daughter, Linda, also lives in Ekerö with her family.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Fältskog has four grandchildren.
section: == Personal life ==
